Title: Governance in Babylon: Negotiating the Rule of Three Empires (GoviB)

This project, Governance in Babylon: Negotiating the Rule of Three Empires (GoviB), seeks to investigate the dynamics of governance in ancient Babylon during the late 8th century BC to the 4th century BC, a period marked by the successive rule of the Assyrian, Chaldean, and Persian Empires. Focusing on local negotiations of imperial rule and the strategies employed by rulers to maintain stability or instigate instability, this study aims to deepen our understanding of politics and authority in Babylon during this transformative period. Despite the challenges posed by incomplete historical data and ambivalent or conflicting interpretations, GoviB will leverage a unique combination of textual materials from Neo-Babylonian archival texts, archaeological findings from German excavations in Babylon, and resources from the Vorderasiatische Museum in Berlin.

By applying a governance studies conceptual framework, this project will evaluate the empires' roles in cultural transformation and reassess modern perceptions of "oriental governance" and "regime stability." The expected outcomes of GoviB include a nuanced understanding of the complex interplay between imperial powers and local populations, as well as a critical reevaluation of the legacies of these ancient empires. Ultimately, this research will contribute to a richer understanding of the evolution of governance and its continued relevance to contemporary debates on authority, power, and cultural exchange.
